channel.title: Stories from theringer.com - Digg
channel.description: Archive of the best theringer.com stories on Digg including articles, videos, and photos

item.title: Social Distancing Diaries: Surviving A Virtual School Day
item.description: The physical and mental challenges of quarantine are daunting enough. Add two screaming kids and teaching kindergarten to the mix? Anarchy.

item.title: The Complicated Truths Of Dr. Dre's 'The Chronic'
item.description: No rap album has quite the mythology attached to it — as a game changer, a king maker, a genre expander. But legends aren't exactly fact.

item.title: Where Does Scottie Pippen Rank Among The NBA's All-Time Greats?
item.description: Only Jordan was a better all-around player in the '90s... and that was debatable.

item.title: 'Too Hot To Handle' Is Netflix's Most Disconcerting Reality TV Show Yet
item.description: Ten contestants are invited to an island, prohibited from having sex, and encouraged to become "authentically connected." This is not "Love Is Blind." It is something much, much worse.
item.kicker: BAD FOR THEM, GOOD FOR US

item.title: The Quarantine Chess Tournament That Could Change The Game Forever
item.description: After the FIDE Candidates tournament was postponed due to the coronavirus, world champion Magnus Carlsen decided to take things into his own hands. His version of chess could speed the game up permanently.

item.title: 'Who Wants To Be A Millionaire' Is Back — And It Wants To Be A Megahit Again
item.description: For those of us nostalgic for the "Who Wants To Be A Millionaire?" quiz books that so many families kept in their bathroom reading baskets and for the ubiquity of the phrase "phone a friend," good news: "Millionaire" is back. But it's not quite the same. Can this revamped version recapture its old charm?

item.title: Twenty Years Later, 'American Psycho' Has Only Grown More Timely
item.description: Patrick Bateman's search for identity in Mary Harron's 2000 film is a story that's inched closer and closer to our modern existence.

item.title: 'Who Wants To Be A Millionaire' Wants To Be A Megahit Again
item.description: ABC has rolled out a celebrity edition of what was once the most popular program on television, this time helmed by Jimmy Kimmel. Can the game show become a hit again?

item.title: An Examination Of Christian Bale's 12 Best Roles
item.description: Looking at the actor's most important performances, 20 years on from his breakout in "American Psycho."

item.title: The Strokes Are Still Ultra Cool And Totally Exhausted — Just 20 Years Older
item.description: "The New Abnormal," the band's first record since 2013, is a different record from the old Strokes you remember, but it shares a thread with their classics.

item.title: The Sweet Science Of Baking While Sheltering In Place
item.description: Retreating to our kitchens offers a sense of calm and clarity in these uncertain times.

item.title: The 'Parasite' Exit Survey
item.description: With the Best Picture-winning film hitting Hulu on Wednesday, the Ringer staff took a trip back to the Park family's modern, foreboding mansion.

item.title: How Do You Throw A Kid's Birthday Party In Quarantine?
item.description: It's hard to get the tempo of "Happy Birthday" right over Zoom, but everyone's health is more important.

item.title: The Streaming Guide: 10 'Twin Peaks' Descendants To Watch
item.description: Thirty years ago on Wednesday, the boldest, wildest show to ever hit prime-time TV premiered. Since then, neither television nor movies have been the same.

item.title: How Sports Radio Hosts Became America's Grief Counselors
item.description: Longtime broadcasters like Mike Francesa and Paul Finebaum have shifted their shows to reflect the coronavirus pandemic. And they're making their audiences rethink how they see the world.

item.title: What Is The Best 'Movie Song' Of All Time?
item.description: From "Edelweiss" to "Whoop That Trick," we're paying homage to the most memorable songs ever created—and performed—in a film.

item.title: When The Backyard Is The Only Place For Your Kids To Go
item.description: Even in the middle of a pandemic, kids will need to play to release all of that specifically childlike energy. The worst part is reminding them that they can't play like they used to.

item.title: The 'Jeopardy!' College Championship Is Here To Fill The Sporting Void
item.description: Desperate to watch some kind of previously unaired competition? "Jeopardy!" has you covered.

item.title: Quibi's 'Murder House Flip' Is Exactly What It Sounds Like
item.description: Welcome to the first show to combine true crime and HGTV.

item.title: Is Quibi A Good Idea?
item.description: Two television writers debate whether or not the soon-to-be-launched short-form, celebrity-led streaming service will find an audience.

item.title: Mike Schur On The Organic Creation Of Iconic TV
item.description: The writer and showrunner breaks down the science behind Ron Swanson, Leslie Knope, and your "Office" favorites.

item.title: A Summer With No Slams
item.description: The tennis schedule has not been spared the desolation wreaked by the coronavirus. But perhaps no other sport features so many epic champions at the late stages of their careers.

item.title: A Bodacious Oral History Of The Original 'Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles' Movie
item.description: If you were a kid that grew up in the 1990s, a big part of your life revolved around the Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles. The first movie helped usher in Turtle Mania (action figures/video games) and The Ringer's Alan Siegel wrote a very enjoyable oral history of the film, with interviews with the director, cast and creators of the franchise. In this comprehensive article, you'll learn that Jim Henson was a big bowling buff and discover how the elaborate costumes really worked. A fantastic nostalgia rush and a fascinating account of what it was like making the movie behind the scenes. Cowabunga!

item.title: The Most Redundant Characters In TV Shows Of This Century That Should Have Been Cut Out
item.description: For every great hero or memorable villain, there are characters that are just total duds and do nothing to help the show. From the Sand Snakes of "Game of Thrones" to all the newcomers at the end of "Scrubs," here are the least helpful characters in TV shows this century.

item.title: The Least Helpful TV Characters Of The Century
item.description: From Randy of "That '70s Show" to Mark from "Parks and Recreation," these are the characters that added nothing to, or totally derailed, some of the best shows of the past 20 years.

item.title: All Anti, No Hero: Pete Campbell And The Failsons Of 21st Century TV
item.description: While the Tony Sopranos and Don Drapers of the world have defined the modern era of TV, there's another trope — outlined by Michael Scott, Kendall Roy and Gob Bluth — that speaks to our times even better.

item.title: 'So I Says…': Chris Farley Could Make Anything Funny
item.description: How a long-lost "Saturday Night Live" sketch sums up the late comedian's greatness.

item.title: Chris Farley Should Be Remembered For His Grace, Not His Falls
item.description: The funniest person to ever break a table was so much more than just that

item.title: Green Screen: The Oral History Of 'Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'
item.description: No one believed in a movie about four overgrown turtles who are trained in martial arts and named after Italian artists. Then it made more than $200 million and launched a nationwide phenomenon.

item.title: The Best TV Character Of The Century Bracket
item.description: It's time to celebrate all our greatest small-screen figures tournament-style, from bosses like Tony Soprano to millennials like Fleabag, from scene stealers like Tyrion Lannister to wild cards like Michael Scott.

item.title: The Case For Peggy Olson As The 21st Century's Best TV Character, As Explained By Elisabeth Moss
item.description: We spoke to the "Mad Men" star about what her iconic character meant to her, how she grew alongside Peggy, and the television performances that still wow her.

item.title: Amazon Is Buying Its Way To Streaming Wars Supremacy
item.description: When the company wanted to get into the food delivery business, it simply acquired Whole Foods. Now that it's looking to break into reality TV with a "Project Runway" facsimile called "Making the Cut," it has simply acquired the former stars of "Project Runway."

item.title: The Strangest, Funniest And Most Fascinating Baseball-Reference Pages
item.description: Hank Aaron, 1,000-home-run hitter? Check. A player who may have emerged from the Atlantic Ocean? Double check. In these days without MLB, our staff writers went on a deep dive of baseball's most complete database to find things that remind them of what makes the sport so great.

item.title: Self-Isolation In A Small Town
item.description: The coronavirus has slowed down the pace of human activity in cities. In a small college town, the sudden stillness is not so severe. But the pace of felt change has accelerated, resulting in a similarly disorienting effect.

item.title: The Perilous Future Of Gambling In The Time Of The Coronavirus
item.description: Professional sports have halted. Casinos are closed. Social distancing has shut down home games. What's a gambler to do? Virtual marble racing, anyone?

item.title: 40 Classic Sports Games and Moments to Revisit While Social Distancing
item.description: Consider this your streaming guide to sports nostalgia, from Secretariat winning the Belmont to the Warriors blowing a 3-1 series lead.
item.kicker: BACK IN THE TIME OF CLUTCH

item.title: A Guide To Binge-Watching 'Survivor'
item.description: With 39 seasons in the bank, catching up can be a daunting task, but it can be done

item.title: Ranking Rick Dalton's Movie Roles In 'Once Upon A Time… In Hollywood'
item.description: With new movie releases paused indefinitely, one staffer parsed "Lancer," "Hullabaloo," "Operazione Dyn-o-mite!" and the rest of Leonardo DiCaprio's two-level-deep performances from Quentin Tarantino's most recent film.
item.kicker: THE ROLES WITHIN A ROLE OF A LIFETIME

item.title: The 50 Best Episodes Of 'The Office'
item.description: It's not easy to trim down the list of the greatest installments of 'The Office,' but on the show's 15th anniversary, we gave it a shot.

item.title: If The NBA Season Is Over, Who Should Win MVP?
item.description: No player in history has dominated like LeBron James this late in his career, but few players have dominated like Giannis Antetokounmpo, period.

item.title: Nine Extremely Long, Extremely Good Movies
item.description: From "The Right Stuff" to "Hoop Dreams," these aren't just time-wasters, but movies that use their extended running times as weapons.

item.title: It's Time To Ditch Toilet Paper Forever And Embrace The Bidet
item.description: The COVID-19 pandemic has sparked a countrywide toilet-paper-buying frenzy. But there's a better way to clean up that's good for your butt, your wallet and the environment.

item.title: The First-Ever Fictional Doctor Dinner
item.description: What TV and movie doctor characters would you invite to a fictional doctors-only dinner?

item.title: Why The 2020 Olympics Refuse To Accept The Inevitable
item.description: As the number of COVID-19 cases skyrockets worldwide, it's clear to virtually everyone that the Tokyo Games should be postponed. So why does the IOC keep operating as if things will go on as planned?
item.kicker: WE NEED TO TALK ABOUT TOKYO

item.title: Every Episode Of 'Curb Your Enthusiasm,' Ranked
item.description: From "Porn Gil" to "The Black Swan" and everything in between, here is our updated countdown of each episode of Larry David's masterpiece.
item.kicker: SO LONG, THANKS FOR ALL THE AWKWARDNESS

item.title: Forty Questions About Gal Gadot's Celebrity-Filled 'Imagine' Video
item.description: Wonder Woman got Mark Ruffalo, Sia, Will Ferrell, Amy Adams and more to sing John Lennon, and while the video doesn't help, per se, it does give us a moment of distraction to do what we love: joke about celebrities.
item.kicker: IMAGINE ALL THE CELEBRITIES, LEAVING US ALONE

item.title: Where Does the NBA Go From Here?
item.description: How the league is plotting a course forward in the face of a global pandemic
item.kicker: A POST-COVID LEAGUE WILL BE DIFFERENT

item.title: Movies, Minus The Theaters: How Hollywood Is Grappling With The Coronavirus
item.description: With theaters closing and productions shutting down around the world, the film industry is temporarily on hold, forced into backup plans that could have permanent consequences

item.title: The Tom Brady-Buccaneers Marriage Isn't As Weird As You Think
item.description: The greatest quarterback of all time is going to... Tampa Bay? It may seem like an odd marriage at first, but a deeper look at the details shows this union makes plenty of sense for both sides.
item.kicker: ALL IS FAIR IN SPORTS AND GAMES

item.title: The Streaming Canon
item.description: An exhaustive guide to everything streaming has to offer, from Dad Movies to bad reality TV, from rom-coms to Michael Bay-style explosions.
